input.name: Input Switch
input.description: A manual toggle switch. Click to flip between 0 and 1. The source of your signal.
input.learningNote: In hardware, this might be a physical switch connected to VCC or GND.

output.name: Output LED
output.description: A light-emitting diode. Shines when the input is 1 (High). Visualizes your results.
output.learningNote: The final state of your logic. In reality, it converts electrical energy into light.

clock.name: Clock Signal
clock.description: A regular pulse that alternates between 0 and 1. Essential for sequential logic.
clock.learningNote: Synchronizes changes. The heartbeat of the processor.

transistor.name: Transistor (NPN)
transistor.description: The fundamental building block. A small current at the base controls a larger current between collector and emitter.
transistor.learningNote: Transistors are the atoms of computing. Billions of them work together in your CPU.

not.name: NOT Gate (Inverter)
not.description: Flips the input. If input is 1, output is 0. If input is 0, output is 1.
not.learningNote: Built with a single transistor that shorts the output to ground when active.

and.name: AND Gate
and.description: Output is 1 only when ALL inputs are 1. Think of it as a series circuit - all switches must be ON.
and.learningNote: In the real world, this is two transistors in SERIES. Both must conduct for current to flow.

or.name: OR Gate
or.description: Output is 1 when ANY input is 1. Think of it as a parallel circuit - any switch being ON works.
or.learningNote: In the real world, this is two transistors in PARALLEL. Either one conducting allows current to flow.

nand.name: NAND Gate
nand.description: NOT-AND: The universal gate. Output is 0 only when ALL inputs are 1. You can build ANY other gate using only NANDs!
nand.learningNote: NAND is called 'universal' because you can create AND, OR, NOT, and XOR using only NAND gates!

nor.name: NOR Gate
nor.description: NOT-OR: Another universal gate. Output is 1 only when ALL inputs are 0.
nor.learningNote: The Apollo Guidance Computer that landed on the Moon was built entirely from NOR gates!

xor.name: XOR Gate (Exclusive OR)
xor.description: Output is 1 only when inputs are DIFFERENT. Essential for binary addition.
xor.learningNote: XOR is the heart of binary addition. 1+1=10 in binary, and XOR gives you the '0' (the sum bit).

physicsNotes.timing: Higher delay than AND/OR due to transmission gates

xnor.name: XNOR Gate (Equivalence)
xnor.description: Output is 1 only when inputs are THE SAME. It is a comparator.
xnor.learningNote: XNOR is used in equality comparators - it tells you if two bits are the same.

halfAdder.name: Half Adder
halfAdder.description: Adds two single bits. Outputs a SUM and a CARRY. Built from XOR + AND.
halfAdder.learningNote: The first step to building a calculator! Sum = A XOR B, Carry = A AND B.

physicsNotes.delay: Critical path through XOR (longer than AND)
physicsNotes.composition: Two half adders + OR = full adder

fullAdder.name: Full Adder
fullAdder.description: Adds three bits (A, B, and Carry-In). Can be chained for multi-bit addition.
fullAdder.learningNote: Chain 4 full adders together and you have a 4-bit calculator!

physicsNotes.criticalPath: Carry chain determines max clock speed
physicsNotes.optimization: CLA (Carry-Lookahead) reduces O(n) to O(log n)

srLatch.name: SR Latch
srLatch.description: The simplest memory element. Set (S) turns it ON, Reset (R) turns it OFF. It REMEMBERS its state.
srLatch.learningNote: This is how your computer remembers things! Two cross-connected NOR gates create a feedback loop.

tristate.name: Tri-State Buffer
tristate.description: Controls if a signal is connected to a bus. When Enable is 0, the output is 'High-Impedance' (disconnected).
tristate.learningNote: Essential for 'Buses' where many components share the same wire. Only one can be enabled at a time to avoid contention!

physicsNotes.hizState: Both NFET and PFET OFF = high impedance
physicsNotes.contention: Two drivers = short circuit, undefined voltage

dFlipFlop.name: D Flip-Flop
dFlipFlop.description: Stores 1 bit of data. The output copies the input only when the clock ticks.
dFlipFlop.learningNote: Every register in your CPU is made of these. They synchronize everything to the clock signal.

mux2to1.name: 2-to-1 Multiplexer
mux2to1.description: A data selector. The SELECT input chooses which of the two data inputs to pass through.
mux2to1.learningNote: If Select=0, output=A. If Select=1, output=B. This is how CPUs route data!

physicsNotes.delay: Transmission gate MUX is faster, lower power

tflipflop.name: T Flip-Flop
tflipflop.description: Toggle flip-flop: when T=1 and clock rises, the output toggles (flips to opposite state). When T=0, the output holds.
tflipflop.physicsNote: Built from a D-FF with Q̅ XOR T feedback. Key building block for binary counters: each stage toggles when all lower bits are 1.
tflipflop.learningNote: Connect T=1 and you get a divide-by-2 frequency divider. Chain them together to build a binary counter!

jkflipflop.name: JK Flip-Flop
jkflipflop.description: Universal flip-flop with Set, Reset, Hold, and Toggle modes. J=1 sets, K=1 resets, J=K=1 toggles, J=K=0 holds.
jkflipflop.physicsNote: Evolved from SR latch to eliminate the forbidden state. Master-slave construction prevents race-around. Can emulate any other FF type.
jkflipflop.learningNote: The 'Swiss Army knife' of flip-flops! Wire J=K for T-FF behavior, or D→J, D̅→K for D-FF behavior.
